data.text: Contents
Process for Conscious Sedation ................................... Error! Bookmark not defined.
Introduction

Concerns have been raised both nationally and locally, in the light of large national studies and local adverse incident reports about the safety of practice for conscious sedation. In particular, the use of high strength Midazolam in conscious sedation has raised specific concerns and its mis-selection is included in the current NHS England Never Event list.
This policy reflects recommendations made by the National Patient Safety Agency NPSA (2008).
Scope
The purpose of this document is to describe the standards which are expected to be applied in patients given sedation procedures in the Trust.

This document does not outline specific management of sedation within specialties. Clinical specialities are responsible for ensuring specific sedation protocols/ guidelines are in place across all relevant services.
Definitions

table_items.text: The ASA physical status classification system is a system for assessing the fitness of patients before surgery.

May be formal (e.g. domiciliary care workers) or informal (e.g. relatives) and are to be considered for the scope of this document any person who prompts, assists or administers medication to patients.

This form of moderate sedation is where there is depression of consciousness during which patients respond purposefully to verbal commands, either alone or accompanied by light tactile stimulation. (NB reflex withdrawal from a painful stimulus is NOT considered a purposeful response). No interventions are required to maintain a patent airway, and spontaneous ventilation is adequate. Cardiovascular function is usually maintained.

This form of sedation has depression of consciousness during which patients cannot be easily aroused but respond purposefully following repeated or painful stimulation. The ability to independently maintain ventilator. Function is impaired. Patients require assistance in maintaining a patent airway and spontaneous ventilation may be inadequate. Cardiovascular function is usually maintained.
A temporary state of depression of the central nervous system during which the patient is unaware and unable to respond to
their external environment, unable to protect their airway and may exhibit profound depression of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems.
5mg/ml or 2mg/ml strength preparation. At the Trust the product available is 10mg/2ml ampoules.
1mg/ml strength preparation. At the Trust the products include 5mg/5ml, 2mg/2ml and 50mg/50ml presentations.

A state of anxiolysis during which patients respond normally to verbal command or can be woken up to full consciousness by minimal stimuli. Although cognitive function and coordination may be impaired, ventilatory and cardiovascular functions are unaffected.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Patient Safety and Quality Group
Receiving exception reports and taking action in response to issues raised from Medicines Assurance Group and/or department of pharmacy.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nurse or site Director of Nursing and Chief Medical Officer or site Medical Director as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning conscious sedation.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Escalating issues to site divisional governance groups and MAG as appropriate.
Chief Executive

As the Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date documents in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Medical Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the site Medical Directors that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated conscious sedation issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site and Divisional Clinical/Medical Directors
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated conscious sedation issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Division Medical Directors for departments performing procedures under conscious sedation

Ensuring there is a lead clinician responsible for establishing departmental guidelines for sedation. Guidelines should include assessment, training, drug regimens, patient monitoring, discharge criteria, monitoring of standards and complications.
Ensuring staff within their specialty are adequately trained as outlined in this policy and local divisional guidance.
Division Medical Director overseeing Anaesthetic Department
Ensuring there is clinical support provided to departments (performing procedures under conscious sedation) to ensure a safe framework exists for conscious sedation within the departments.
Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the Site Pharmacy, Head of Department that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated conscious sedation issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Director of Nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated conscious sedation issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for conscious sedation across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standard.
The Chief Pharmacist delegates this responsibility to the site Pharmacy Heads of Department and specialty clinical leadership Pharmacists for delivery.
Staff performing procedure under conscious sedation
Ensuring that they are adequately trained, are competent and have adequate staff and resources to perform the procedure safely adhering to this policy's requirements.
Anaethetist or Sedationist for the procedure
Ensuring that they are adequately trained, are competent and have adequate staff and resources to perform the procedure safely adhering to this policy's requirements;
Giving the drugs, monitoring patient safety, comfort and wellbeing and communicate significant changes to the clinician and making a written record;
Ensuring that they, or a suitably skilled member of their team, remain
immediately available to respond and attend to the consequences of their actions.
Prescribers
Ensuring that they are adequately trained, are competent and have adequate staff and resources to perform the procedure safely adhering to this policy's requirements.
Registered Nursing staff
Ensuring patients are appropriately monitored during and after their procedure in line with this policy and departmental documents for sedation procedures.
Process for conscious sedation

Prior to progressing on the process, each patient case must be assessed for the need for conscious sedation (particularly using the intravenous route). Alternatives including local anaesthesia must be considered. The rationale for each case must be documented. The type of procedure or patient anxiety will be primary reasons. Risk factors that may increase the potential for side effects such as respiratory depression include old age, obesity, hepatic impairment and low resting oxygen saturations.
Any individual prescribing or administering sedation must be familiar with the concepts and safe practices of conscious sedation.

A pre-sedation assessment must be completed, to include a review of the patient's past and present medical and drug history with a formal documentation of risk (e.g. ASA grade). Anaesthetic support should be obtained if unable to evaluate ASA grade.
Patient's must have capacity and consent to treatment, as per any other Trust procedure performed for a patient. Please refer to Trust consenting policy (or equivalent).

Patients must be appropriately fasted for any procedure involving sedation as there always remains the risk of the loss of protective airway reflexes and aspiration (six hours for food, 2 hours for water). Tea and coffee with milk, fruit juices and milk must be considered as food, and the timings not considered amenable to interpretation.

As the use of sedation can obtund a patient's response, the use of the theatres WHO checklist (2009) must be used to ensure the correct procedure on the correct site is carried out and the team is made aware of any patient specific concerns.
Treatment plans for sedation

5.7.1 A written plan for the patient's sedation, including indication / rationale, total dose of sedation, appropriate consent and monitoring must be present in the patient record, based on local clinical guidelines where available.
5.7.2 The plan must include criteria for terminating monitoring and deeming full recovery to have occurred.

5.7.3 The plan must account for the patient's individual needs including those determined by age and organ function relevant to the proposed sedation and account for but not discriminate due to pre-existing disability.
5.7.4 Any appropriate deviation from a policy or approved guidelines needs to be documented, with reasons, in the medical record.

5.7.5 Any clinical staff who suspect at any stage that the plan and implementation of that plan has deviated inappropriately from a policy or approved guidelines should complete a clinical incident report via the Trust incident reporting system and inform the senior clinician.
5.7.6 The use of a reversing agent to reverse an accidental state of deep sedation is never regarded as routine, even if a pre-specified option and a clinical incident report must be completed.
A minimum of two personnel must be involved in the care of patients undergoing conscious sedation during the entire procedure and these should be:
5.8.1 The clinician who performs the procedure.

5.8.2 The anaesthetist / sedationist whose sole responsibility is to give the drugs, monitor patient safety, comfort and wellbeing and communicate significant changes to the operator and making a written record. Blood pressure and Pulse oximetry must be recorded as an absolute minimum. A standardised monitoring proforma should be used wherever possible based on locally developed clinical guidelines. They must ensure that they, or a suitably skilled member of their team, remain immediately available to respond and attend to the consequences of their actions.

Where patients are sent to Diagnostic Imaging, any patient specifically prescribed a sedative agent must be accompanied by a competent registered nurse and have blood pressure and pulse oximetry continuously monitored.

Venous access with a flexible (i.e. not butterfly) cannula must be secured. Where consent is not obtained for this, a patient specific risk assessment is mandatory, and the outcome clearly documented in the patient record.
Where an opioid is given in combination with a sedative, the opioid should be given first and allowed time to become maximally effective before any sedative is added.

It should be recognised that generally only one sedative drug should be used to minimise the risks. Of note, as some procedures are painful, excessive doses of sedatives should not be used to overcome response to painful stimuli; appropriate sedation techniques should be used which may include the use of analgesics.
Equipment that must be present and functioning:
Blood pressure and ECG monitoring (although ECG may not be necessary in young healthy adult patients, it must be available and used in those with cardiovascular problems);
Pulse oximeter;

Source of supplemental oxygen and apparatus for delivery – it should be utilised if there is any concern that the saturations may fall below the resting figure. A reading of less than 90% is potentially dangerous and requires immediate intervention;
Suction apparatus with appropriate suction catheters;
Cardiac arrest trolley immediately available;
Patient bed/trolleys should be capable of being tipped head down (if procedure excludes this a specific risk assessment is necessary).

Individuals prescribing or administering sedation that has the potential to lead to compromise of the airway or breathing must have basic competencies in airway management, ensure that all appropriate equipment necessary for this is immediately available and they are familiar with its use.

During and after the course of sedation, the patient must be monitored and observations recorded as a minimum every 15 minutes. Oxygen administration is recommended throughout and after the procedure.
After a procedure, the patient must continue to be monitored by pulse oximetry until fully awake. Immediate intervention is required if oxygen saturations <90%.
Patients may be discharged home or removed from special monitoring criteria if:
They have been observed for at least one hour (or 4 hours if they required assisted ventilation or reversal agent);
They must be fully awake;
They must be able to walk without assistance (or as before procedure).

If moderate sedation is to be used, and an antagonist exists for that sedative, sufficient antagonist to reverse any accidental overdose situation is to be verified as immediately available in that clinical area. It should be recognised that Flumazenil, the antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, can have side-effects such as seizures, therefore it should only be used in extreme circumstances and not as a matter of routine.
If verbal responsiveness is lost, the patient requires a level of care identical to that needed for general anaesthesia.
If sedation is used for outpatients, the department must have processes in place to ensure patients are adequately supervised on discharge (e.g. accompanied when
leaving) and given appropriate advice regarding the effects of sedation e.g. not to drive / operate machinery or make key decisions for at least 24 hours after.
There must be adherence to any departmental policies where it specifies:
The minimal experience and number of clinical staff to be present;
A specific formulation for a drug for an indication;
The maximum amount of a sedative to be pre-prepared (i.e. drawn up) before a procedure based on age or weight or other patient variable.

A clinical incident must be completed where patient harm has occurred as a result of sedation, the sedation progresses to deep sedation (e.g. loss of verbal responsiveness), a reversing agent is used when its use was unplanned or this policy has been transgressed. All clinical incidents must be actioned by the Clinical Directorate/Divisional Lead.
All near misses / near misses by intervention must also be escalated to the Clinical Directorate/Divisional Lead. This is also a reportable incident.
Medication
Maintenance of an adequate range of analgesic, sedative and resuscitative drugs is the responsibility of a specified individual within each department where sedation is undertaken.
Expiry dates of drugs must be checked in accordance with Trust policy.
Drugs must be stored in accordance with Trust policy.
Clear labelling of syringes containing drugs is required.
Specific antagonists for intravenous sedatives must be immediately accessible. These must not be used to facilitate excessive dosing or to enhance rapid recovery prior to discharge.
Disposal of waste controlled drugs must be witnessed and the controlled drug register must always be kept up to date.
Midazolam use
One strength only of midazolam is ever available for use within a clinical area. This is either a low strength (1mg/1ml) or high strength (10mg/2ml). Please see MSEPO- 20237 Controlled Drugs Policy.
Only the 1mg/1ml strength is to be used for conscious sedation, available in clinical areas carrying out procedures.
10mg/2ml must only be used for palliative care patients for subcutaneous administration.
The holding of Midazolam 1mg/1ml strengths in clinical areas requires the approval of the site Clinical Lead Pharmacist (or equivalent) and the Clinical Lead for the relevant clinical specialty.
Midazolam 1mg/1ml must never be lent to another clinical area.
Midazolam 10mg/2ml must only be lent to a ward outside of pharmacy opening hours when it is for the purpose of palliative care. Refer to MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy.
Local clinical guidelines must be in place to ensure appropriate use of Midazolam covering use of aliquots, dosing intervals, maximum treatment doses and adjustments for elderly / co-morbidities.

If it is considered that higher doses than stated within the guidelines are required, the individual case must be discussed with an anaesthetist or a consultant within the specialty and the outcome documented in the medical notes.
Opioids (intravenous)
Local clinical guidelines will be in place to ensure appropriate use, including provision for dosing in the elderly and those with co-morbidities.
The concomitant use of a sedative and opioid should be carefully considered before proceeding, particularly in the elderly.
Flumazenil reversal
Flumazenil is stocked in every clinical location where midazolam is stocked in the Trust.
Local clinical guidelines will be in place to ensure appropriate use.
When flumazenil is used, an incident report shall be submitted by the clinical area on the Trust incident reporting system.
Training requirements

All members of the team involved in providing sedation need to have knowledge of sedation techniques and be aware of their role in the event of serious complications. Those members of the team who are involved in administering sedation whilst performing a procedure need further training in the provision, monitoring and treatment of the complications of conscious sedation.

Training covering the following must be evidenced (either as part of a comprehensive sedation training program or as standalone sessions). These should be recorded via the Trust's online Learning Management System for audit purposes to include as a minimum:
Background to local / national regulations;
Assessment of patients;
Cardio-respiratory and neurological physiology;
Clinical pharmacology;
Applied anatomy;
Cannulation skills;
Airway management skills;
Function and limitations of monitoring equipment;
Basic and advanced life support.
Outcomes of training will be that teams working within the Trust offering a sedation service should be able to:
State the indications and contra-indications for the use of sedation techniques and methods of assessment of patients;
Describe the sedation techniques provided by the service;
Define the number of staff and their skills, present during procedures carried out under conscious sedation;
Ensure staff administering the sedation techniques are appropriately and adequately trained and describe how they will maintain their skills;
Ensure systems are in place for monitoring of patients, record keeping, monitoring of the outcomes of the use of sedation and demonstrate that local and national guidelines are being followed.
The lead clinician within each department will be responsible for ensuring staff within their specialty are adequately trained.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Divisional Governance Meetings and site Medicines Optimisation & Safety Group.
Divisional Governance Meetings Medicines Assurance Group
Pharmacy usage reports Review of incident reports

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by Medicines Assurance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform all prescribers, nursing and pharmacy of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
References

London: Association of Anaesthetists of Great Britain and Ireland. Available at : www.anaesthetists.org/Home/Resources- publications/Guidleines/Recommendations-for-standards-of-monitoring-during- anaesthesia-and-recovery-2021

London:BSG. Available at: www.bsg.org.uk/clinical-resource/deep-sedation-and-anaesthesia-in-complex- gastrointestinal-endoscopy/
NHS England (2018). Never event list. London:NHS England. Available at: www.england.nhs.uk/patient-safety/revised-never-events-policy-and- framework/#Reviewing-the-2018-Never-Events-List
NPSA (2008). Rapid Response Report RRR011: Reducing the risk of overdose with Midazolam injection in adults.

Academy of Medical Royal Colleges, 2013. Safe sedation practice for healthcare procedures: standards and guidance. London:AOMRC. Available at: www.aomrc.org.uk/reports-guidance/safe-sedation-practice-1213/
World Health Organization, 2009. Implementation manual WHO surgical safety checklist 2009. WHO:Geneva. Available at: www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241598590
